Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Sustainability of Riparian Forests in Expanding Amazonian Agricultural Landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conversion of large areas of Amazon forest vegetation for intensive crop production is one of the major forces shaping the Earth. Riparian forest buffers along streams can reduce the potential negative effects of forest clearing on stream water quality and stream habitat by intercepting nutrients, providing shade to reduce temperature and protecting stream channels. This project investigates how deforestation, cropland expansion and intensification, and increased fertilizer use influence the structure and sustainability of riparian forests, and ultimately affect their capacity to keep nutrient runoff from reaching streams. Research will take place in the Amazon state of Mato Grosso, Brazil's global hotspot of deforestation where soybean cultivation has expanded rapidly in the last two decades. Producers in the region are now shifting from single-cropped soybeans to double-cropped soybeans and corn, which greatly increases fertilizer inputs. This project addresses the globally important issue of how to protect and sustain water quality and aquatic resources in tropical regions, where high deforestation and rapid cropland expansion are increasingly common. By improving understanding of the trajectories and causes of riparian forest change and predicting the movement of nitrogen through riparian zones, these results will provide a basis for managing the negative impacts of tropical agricultural intensification. The project team will convey findings to policymakers and farmers in Brazil and the US by conducting two workshops on the scientific basis for riparian forest management and conservation.

This project will investigate whether riparian forest fragments in cropland maintain their vegetation structure over time and how that structure is influenced by alterations to watershed hydrology and microclimate that are typical of cropland areas. Investigators will determine whether riparian forests bordering streams in croplands intercept and remove nitrogen from watersheds and whether this nitrogen removal function is sufficient to prevent excess nitrogen from reaching streams in cropland watersheds with high fertilizer inputs. The project will quantify how changes to riparian forest structure in croplands alter stream temperature, metabolism, nutrient uptake and downstream nutrient export. This will be accomplished by comparing riparian forests in replicated watersheds within intact tropical forest, soybean-only cropland and soybean-corn cropland. The project focuses on the following three hypotheses: (1) Riparian forests in cropland watersheds have higher tree mortality, lower tree growth and a more open canopy than either upland forests or riparian forests in forested watersheds. (2) Cropland watersheds have lower evapotranspiration, greater runoff and nutrient export, higher water tables, and wetter stream side slopes than forest watersheds but denitrification in riparian zones is insufficient to prevent excess nitrogen from reaching streams in double-cropped watersheds. (3) More open canopies in cropland riparian forest will increase stream temperature and metabolism. This project will create a new conceptual framework for understanding how deforestation, cropland expansion, and agricultural intensification influence tropical riparian forests and streams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The conversion of large areas of Amazon forest vegetation to crop agriculture is one of the major forces shaping the Earth. Riparian forests?the strips of forest bordering streams?can reduce the potential negative effects of forest clearing on stream water quality and stream habitat by intercepting nutrients, providing shade to reduce water temperature, protecting stream channel habitats, and providing corridors of forest in increasingly agricultural landscapes. This project tracked the composition of riparian forests left along streams in Amazon croplands and compared them with similar riparian forests within large, intact blocks of remaining forest. It also compared the characteristics of the small streams within the riparian forests in cropland and forested landscapes. Because the crops that are expanding into Amazon forest require the use of large amounts of nitrogen and phosphorus fertilizers, this project also tracked the fate of these fertilizers and tested whether fertilizer use on Amazon croplands increased the concentration and runoff these nutrients in to streams. This project took place in the Brazilian Amazon state of Mato Grosso, a global hotspot of deforestation, expansion of soybean cropland and intensification of agriculture by double cropping of soybeans with corn and other crops that require high amounts of fertilizers. Because riparian forest buffer zones along streams are protected under Brazilian law, this project provides information on how the structure and health of these forests changes over time and how riparian forests protect stream habitat and water quality.

Intellectual Merit

This found that the species diversity of forest trees declined in riparian forests in croplands compared with within larger intact forests. Riparian forest tree species diversity increased with distance from the stream within intact forests, but declined in croplands. Forest tree seedling species richness is much lower in cropland riparian forests. Large trees virtually disappeared from cropland riparian forests. Cropland riparian forest trees on average were shorter, had lighter wood and less dense canopies. These patterns combined to produce forests with lower stature, lower biomass, and less reproduction within croplands. These effects were greatest near the edges of crop fields and decreased inward toward stream channels.

By conducting experiments that tracked the fate of nitrogen under crops fertilized with different amounts of fertilizer, this project also found that Amazon soils under both forest and cropland have the capacity to store large amounts of nitrogen in the form of nitrate at depths of two to six meters. The nitrate storage in soil profiles was higher under soybean-only and soybean-corn cropland compared with forest, and the small difference in nitrate storage in soybean-only and soybean-corn profiles suggested that N fixation by soybeans, or residual N from the original forest clearing, but not application of N fertilizer in soybean-corn cropland was the source of this increased stored nitrate.

The previously unknown ability of Amazon croplands to store nitrate at many meters depth was consistent with the findings from this project that the concentrations of nitrate did not increase in streams draining croplands compared with forests. Solute concentrations and solute export from forest headwater streams were very low in forest and in croplands. Export of nitrogen and phosphorus increased slightly in soybean-only and soybean-corn cropland headwater streams but this increase is proportional to increase in water export and was not influenced by the presence of intensive cropping. Because nitrate is strongly adsorbed by deep soils, little fertilizer nitrogen currently makes it to the groundwater and moves to riparian forests. The ultimate capacity for deep soil nitrate storage is not known but it is very important because it will ultimately determine if nitrate derived from croplands will reach groundwater and streams. It will also determine if a nitrogen removal role for riparian forests, though not operating currently, could protect streams in the future.

Broader Impact

This project found that protection of narrow riparian forests along streams maintains many characteristics of streams in intact forest but that forest composition degraded over time, particularly at forest edges bordering crop fields. The finding that deep soils currently buffer riparian zones and streams from harmful nitrogen runoff was new and potentially important. Understanding the mechanism of this buffering will be critical for determining if the increasing amounts of fertilizer now being applied to Amazon croplands will ultimately degrade water quality as has occurred in many intensive temperate zone cropland regions.

This project supported the research of five US principal investigators and three additional collaborating US faculty. It supported the field studies of two US PhD students at Columbia and Pennsylvania State University, and collaboration of the US research team with six additional Brazilian faculty, four Brazilian post-docs and eight Brazilian graduate students.
